channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Pornhub sued for allegedly serving “under-age, non-consensual” videos
item.description: “I seek justice for myself and the countless victims who don’t come forward.”

item.title: Ring gave cops free cameras to build and promote surveillance network
item.description: LAPD officers “spread the word” for the startup, helping it gain market share.

item.title: Arcade1Up pinball cabinet review: Fine for families, interesting for modders
item.description: The default package is worth its $600 cost, but do your research before buying.

item.title: Apple and Google’s AI wizardry promises privacy—at a cost
item.description: Upgraded data protection and less reliance on the cloud could lock users in.

item.title: Rocket Report: China launches crew mission, SpaceX runs into road troubles
item.description: “The Space Safari team intends to push the envelope.”

item.title: Ukraine arrests ransomware gang in global cybercriminal crackdown
item.description: Arrests of Cl0p hacker group members adds to pressure on other countries to follow suit.

item.title: Game Boy Advance game gets split-screen multiplayer through new FPGA core
item.description: No link-cable needed for this emulated single-machine, single-display solution.

item.title: Newly discovered Vigilante malware outs software pirates and blocks them
item.description: Most malware tries to steal stuff. Vigilante, by contrast, takes aim at piracy.

item.title: Amazon joins Apple, Google by reducing its app store cut
item.description: Developers with revenues under $1 million are getting a new deal.

item.title: A number of recommended Nintendo Switch games are on sale today
item.description: Dealmaster also has early Prime Day discounts, Philips Hue deals, and more.

item.title: Microsoft’s Linux repositories were down for 18+ hours
item.description: The outage prevented Linux installation or upgrade of any Microsoft software.

item.title: FDA officials asked to step down after contentious Alzheimer’s drug approval
item.description: Three experts resigned in protest. Watchdog says it’s FDA brass that should leave.

item.title: Researchers cool a 40 kg object to near its quantum ground state
item.description: Mirrors of the LIGO gravitational-wave detector get cool—extremely cool.

item.title: Here’s what’s inside Google’s first-ever retail store
item.description: Buy a speaker, try Google Stadia, or fix a cracked phone screen—the store is open.

item.title: Peter Jackson’s 6-hour Beatles documentary confirmed for Disney+ this November
item.description: Jackson thanks Beatles, Disney for “allowing me to present this story” as 6-hour beast.

item.title: Bethesda exec says he’s “sorry” for lack of PS5 Starfield
item.description: “I’m certain that’s frustrating… but there’s not a whole lot I can do about it.”

item.title: World Bank slams bitcoin, declines to help El Salvador’s cryptocurrency plan
item.description: Bank faults bitcoin’s “environmental and transparency shortcomings.”

item.title: Lordstown Motors now says that it has no binding orders for EV truck
item.description: It clarified with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has no firm orders.

item.title: SpaceX to break the final frontier in reuse with national defense launch
item.description: Thursday’s GPS mission is a high priority for the Space Force.

item.title: Ohio Republicans close to imposing near-total ban on municipal broadband
item.description: Bill’s 10Mbps standard could make 98% of Ohio ineligible for municipal networks.

item.title: A new HTTP spec proposes elimination of obnoxious “cookie banners”
item.description: Explicit privacy communication mechanism can simplify UI and limit user fatigue.

item.title: Apple’s Tim Cook: Sideloading is “not in the best interests of the user”
item.description: The interview also touched on privacy, AR, health, and future products.

item.title: Ten-year hacktivist fugitive Commander X arrested in Mexico
item.description: “We do not forgive. We do not forget.” But neither do the feds.

item.title: Facebook begins tying social media use to ads served inside its VR ecosystem
item.description: Announcement doubles down on Facebook account requirement for Oculus hardware.

item.title: New Picard S2 teaser taunts us with return of Q, time shenanigans
item.description: Second season doesn’t debut until 2022, but this whets our appetite.

item.title: Amazon blames social media companies for sales of fake Amazon reviews
item.description: Fake Amazon reviews are bought and sold on social media, including Facebook.

item.title: After ruining 75M J&J doses, Emergent gets FDA clearance for 25M doses
item.description: More than 100 million vaccine doses are still in limbo at the facility.

item.title: Forget trailers: The best upcoming games we played at this year’s E3
item.description: You can play (most of) the games on our “Best of E3” list right now for free on PC, Xbox.

item.title: Google enables end-to-end encryption for Android’s default SMS/RCS app
item.description: Both users need Google Messages, RCS needs to be on, and it’s for 1:1 chats only.

item.title: Cold-War-era missile launches three modern-day spy satellites
item.description: The small rockets are not cheap, but they are effective.

item.title: Lina Khan, Big Tech skeptic, named FTC chair mere hours after confirmation
item.description: As chair, Khan could bring a new approach to antitrust enforcement.

item.title: Someone stabbed a cave bear in the head with a spear 35,000 years ago
item.description: It’s a rare piece of evidence of people killing cave bears during the Pleistocene.

item.title: A cold spot and a stellar burp led to strange dimming of Betelgeuse
item.description: The star ejected a gas bubble, and lower temps condensed heavier elements into dust.

item.title: Lordstown has binding orders, says limited production starts this year
item.description: The EV startup will need funds to increase production past 20,000 trucks a year.

item.title: A guide to living at a black hole
item.description: Living next to Ned Flanders won’t teach you as much about the fundamental nature of reality.

item.title: Mercury is accumulating in deep-ocean trenches
item.description: Following mercury around the environment isn’t easy.

item.title: Polestar picks the US to build its next electric vehicle
item.description: The Polestar 3 electric SUV goes into production in 2022.

item.title: Experts “extremely worried” about Delta variant as US death toll hits 600,000
item.description: Vaccines are effective against the variant, but experts worry about low vaccination rates.

item.title: Starlink dishes go into “thermal shutdown” once they hit 122° Fahrenheit
item.description: Man watered dish to cool it down but overheating knocked it offline for 7 hours.

item.title: Medieval people suffered for fashion with their extremely pointy shoes
item.description: Skeletons from 14th and 15th centuries had higher rate of bunions than earlier remains

item.title: A DNA-based storage system with files and metadata
item.description: Queries can take days, but it’s possible to pull out specific files.

item.title: Nintendo deal: Buy a Switch Online Family Membership, get a free 128GB microSD card
item.description: Dealmaster also has new early Prime Day deals, a big Xbox games sale, and more.

item.title: Make way for Windows 11? Windows 10 end-of-life is October 2025
item.description: We’ll find out more about Windows 10’s replacement OS later this month.

item.title: Apple’s podcast subscriptions went live today—with a 30 percent cut
item.description: Creators can set whatever subscription fee they choose or not take part at all.

item.title: Everything Nintendo announced in its E3 2021 “Direct” presentation
item.description: New Warioware and Mario Party, remastered Advance Wars and Monkey Ball, and much more.

item.title: Tim Berners-Lee makes an NFT from World Wide Web’s Objective-C
item.description: Computer scientist assembles digital collectible to capitalize on NFT craze.

item.title: ZFS fans, rejoice—RAIDz expansion will be a thing very soon
item.description: Founding OpenZFS dev Matthew Ahrens opened a pull request last week.

item.title: New trailer shows first gameplay footage for Breath of the Wild sequel
item.description: Zelda sequel takes 2017 original to the skies, now due in 2022.

item.title: BMW finds its mojo again with the $55,400 i4 electric sedan
item.description: The car looks good, the specs look good, and the price looks good.

item.title: Metroid Dread brings Nintendo’s classic back as a 2D sequel on October 8
item.description: Includes flashy 3D cinematics, mechanics from 2017’s 2D revival Samus Returns.

item.title: US warns EU against anti-American tech policy
item.description: NSC has some strong opinions ahead of Biden’s first presidential trip to Brussels.

item.title: Health care CEOs raked in $3.2 billion as pandemic raged
item.description: CEOs’ median pay rose to $9 million despite record layoffs of health workers.

item.title: OnePlus announces the 90 Hz, $240 “Nord N200” for North America
item.description: It has a Snapdragon 480, 4GB of RAM, a headphone jack, microSD slot, and more.

item.title: Todd Howard is finally ready to share some Starfield details
item.description: “300-ish” years from now, the “last space explorers” also explore profound questions.

item.title: Google’s unified Gmail interface (and Google Chat) launches for everyone
item.description: Gmail’s new do-it-all interface is thankfully optional.

item.title: Halo Infinite multiplayer news: Bots, split-screen, free-to-play clarified
item.description: Hints of new announcer system, new firepower, and multiplayer-specific tweaks.

item.title: The Apple Watch Series 7 will have a new design, report says
item.description: Some big features, like a blood sugar sensor, are at least a year away, though.

item.title: Pai’s legacy lives on for now as Biden fails to nominate Democrat to FCC
item.description: Biden’s failure to fill empty FCC slot has consumer advocates increasingly worried.

item.title: Judge slams hospital staff for comparing COVID vaccine mandate to Nazi crimes
item.description: Health care workers sued hospital over a vax mandate they say violates Nuremberg Code.

item.title: Chip shortages lead to more counterfeit chips and devices
item.description: Industry analysts recommend businesses take extra care with the supply chain.

item.title: We have another highly effective COVID vaccine, based on different tech
item.description: While not needed for the US, it should help with the global vaccine push.

item.title: Five new bills aim to break up Big Tech platforms, force them to play nice
item.description: Apple, Google, Facebook, and Amazon would struggle to evade new regulations.

item.title: Beats Studio Buds review: Apple earbuds that don’t leave Android in the dark
item.description: Beats' latest true wireless earbuds have tiny design, active noise cancelation.

item.title: Hands-on: Echo Show 8 is like a tablet grafted onto a smart speaker
item.description: “Alexa, test and review the new Echo Show 8.” “I’m sorry, I don’t know that one.”

item.title: Metals from space descend on Boulder, Colorado, at dusk and dawn
item.description: Sodium and other metals from space make regular—and irregular—landfall on Earth.

item.title: The CEO and CFO of Lordstown Motors both just resigned
item.description: The resignations follow a “going concern” warning earlier in June.

item.title: The Ars Technica Father’s Day 2021 gift guide
item.description: We give a few gifting prompts for the guy who won’t say what he actually wants.

item.title: 16 games to keep an eye on from Sunday’s E3 2021 trailer showcases
item.description: From shooters to puzzles to mail delivery sims, these concepts stood out from the crowd.
